titleStmt.title: A petition presented to the Lords and Commons, by the royall party in the county of Sussex. Also two votes agreed upon by both Houses, for Col. Whaley to prosecute all advantages against those now in armes in the county of Essex. With, a true relation of a great victory in Northamptonshire, obtained by Col. Wayte knight, a Member of the House of Commons. Likewise, a totall defeate given to those forces in Kent, under Sir Richard Hardress at Feversham, (who formerly besieged Dover Castle) by Commissary Gen. Ireton, and Col. Barkstead. Imprimatur G.M.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 9KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal licence. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

Whaley to prosecute all advantages against those now in armes in the county of Essex. With, a true relation of a great victory in Northamptonshire, obtained by Col. Wayte knight, a Member of the House of Commons. notesStmt.note: Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

keywords.term: Great Britain -- History -- Civil War, 1642-1649 -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: A PETITJON PRESENTED TO THE LORDS and COMMONS, BY The Royall Party in the County of SƲSSEX.
Also two Votes agreed on by both Houses, For Col. WHALEY to prosecute all advantages against those now in Armes in the County of ESSEX.
WITH, A true Relation of a great Victory in NORTHAMPTONSHIRE, obtained by Col. WAYTE Knight, a Member of the House of Commons.
LIKEWISE, A. totall defeate given to those forces in KENT, under Sir RICHARD HARDRESS at FEVERSHAM, (who formerly besieged DOVER Castle) by Commissary Gen. Ir • ton, and Col. Barkst • ad.
LONDON, Printed for J. J. MDCXLVIII.

div.head: A totall deseate given to the Royalists in Kent, by the Forces of that Renowned Generall, THOMAS Lord FAIRFAX.

argument.p: In a Letter sent from Rochester, the 9. of Iune 1648. to a Friend.

div.p:
VPon the relieving of Dover Castle by Colonell Rich, and Colonell Hewson, That night b • ing the 6. of June, the Mayor of Dover in the name of himselfe, and the Jurates, Officers, an Inhabitants of Dover, sent a Trump • t to Col. Rich, for an Act of Indempnity, and other things, lest they should oppose him. He denied to grant them any because they refused it, when they might have had it from the Parliament, and so marcht into the Towne, expecting opposition, but the Mayor, and 300, more in Armes, instead of resisting, betooke themselves to the Fort, which was summoned as soone as our Guards wee set in the Town, and
they im • eadialy y • elded. Whereupon he sent a Company of Foot to possesse the Fort, where hee found 70. Barrels of Powder, besides Ordnance, and Armes; He sent another party towards Sandwich, which we hope by this time is surrendred, and another partie to Deale, and Sandon Castles, of which you will shortly have an account. In the meane time Col. Barksteads Regimen, and the horse sent from the Generall, unde Com. Generall Jreton, towards Canterbury, marched thir day neere Feversham, met with a porty from Sir Rich: Hardresse, (who lately besiedged Dover Castle,) Sir Thomas Palmer, sir William Man▪ and divers other Genr. of quallity, d • siring a Parley, which by reason that the Foot upon this expedition designed into Essex, (where there so generall need) was condesended unto, and the matter of the Artilery, instantly agreed to, but the Messenger came away before they were put into a forme and signed; one A •• icle was concluded, That at six of the Clock tomorrow morning we were to enter the Towne, and all the Armes and Ammunition are to brought into the Cathedrall. I for to acquaint you, that our party marched with Ladders instantly to storm the place when Messenger met them, and a party of the Enemies Horse, some 4 miles from the Towne, charged the van of our Horse, we killd one, and • ooke 20. I doubt not but Kent will be soone reduced, which being knowne to the Ships, will be a great inducement to them to returne to the obedience of the Parliament. His Excellency hath sent unto them
by such * persons, who may probably prevaile with them, assuring his indeavours for In • empnity: I am,

div.head: Orders from the Lord Generall for the bringing in of those Horses, taken taken from the Enemy in Kent, to the Quarter Master Generall, for use of the State.
div.p: HIs Excellency the Lord Fairfax made these Orders concerning the Horse that were taken from • he Enemy in Kent,, viz:

I doe hereby order and require, neither of Foot nor Horse, shall march with no more Horse, then what he is mounted on; and for those that have been lately taken as Prizes from the Enemy; as well every private Souldier, as other of Horse or Dragoones, they are to be disposed with speed and care for the publike Service: to bee sent to the
Quarter Master Ge • erall, and he to set some ma • ke on them for the States use: and to send them in to my Secretary for what horses they so agree, and what prises, as well Sadles and other A • mes, which the Souldiers hath not use for: If any Souldier or Office • shall refuse to obey this, they are to have such punishment, as the Articles of War • e doth provide to be inflicted, in case of opposition in that par • icular. This is to be observed from Tewsday or Wednesday, at the farthest, being the 6. of Iune,

The Malignant and Papisticall party in Essex grow very presump • uous; the Honest party hath withdraw themselves from them. The honest men and Towne of Colchester have turnd Sir Charles Lucas forth, and doe cleerely st • nd for the Parli • ment and Army, and doe protest, they will not countenance no such Papisticall Malignants, but are a fortyfying the Towne, and standing upon their owne guard. There is Sir Iohn Hunnywood who hath raised and brought in 2000. Foot and Horse, of honest and well-affected men, who are come from ab • ut Cocksell side in Essex; yet that Malignant party, that is the remainder of Gorings, and they of Lucas F • ction, are very high, and have refused the Ordinance for Indempnity: Upon wh • ch the Parliament hath Voted this Order to Col. Whaly, R • solved that t • is House doth declare, that Coll. Whaley, and the rest of the Parliament Forces, may persue those • hat continue in Armes in the County of Essex against the Parliament, and doe Order that
they forthwith persue them, and p • osecuting their advantages upon them accordingly.

His Excellencie hath sent over more into Essex, a brigade of 3000. Foote and Horse to subdue the Enemy there, Col. Whaley and his party d • th keep • their Randevouz at Wallen Common, neare Barnet wood, and Lucas and Gorings party is about Ingerston, they formerly refused the Ordinance for Indempnity, but now it will not be granted unto them: It is much to be admired that there should be such a plague of judgement and blindn • sse fall upon, the people to think that Goring a • d Lucas two Papists, A • hists, or worse, that these men should sit in the behalf of the Essex Petition, where in the chief scope is a desiring of the fulfilling of the Covenan • : this is a most fearefull spirit of madnesse which is fallen upon the people.

Upon Friday last there came a very presumptious Petition cut of Sussex, who there is no question but Goring and his complices ordered the dr • ft, he h • th been sculking thereabouts any time this 4. months, and his residence hath been much and often at a Parliament mans house, time will discover more: it is a shame to think how this Kingdom hath and is bought and sold.

There hath been within these few dayes likewis • , a plotting contrivance of mischiefe in Hampshire, at Lomer Ash, where there was a great me • t • ng and concourse of people under p • etenc • of Petitioning, but that honourable Col. Norton, hath rais • d Regiment of horse, who soone prevented their mischievous
intentions: The Divel hath his game to play in every County throughout the Kingdom, a man would think, that this late passage in Kent, and the ch • stisement they have had in Wales by the Lieutenant Generalls work, somewhat upon their tempers, Col. Wayte, one of the Knights for the County of Rutland, hath suppressed the body of the enemy that was rising in Lincolnshire, Rutlandshire, and Northamptonshire, by a well-affected party, taken many pri • oners▪ most of which he hath discharged, except those which were the chiefe for them, he sent to the Parl. that he may have a Commission from my Lord Generall, to try them for their lives by Martiall Law, which was granted to them: The House ordered thanks to be sent unto him, for the exceeding good service he had done in those parts.
